Celebrating seven milestones in University's history https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/september/celebrating-seven-milestones-in-university-s-history Legacy of Leicester campaign highlights world-class University achievements The University\ufffd\ufffdis\ufffd\ufffdto celebrate seven milestones in its academic history -\ufffd\ufffdone for each of the decades since University College Leicester received the Royal Charter to become a University\ufffd\ufffd-\ufffd\ufffdat the start of the new academic year.

The Legacy of Leicester is a campaign that highlights the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds world-class achievements and reflects the breadth of its groundbreaking research.

2014 will mark the final year in his term as Vice-Chancellor for Professor Sir Robert Burgess and the year will also mark the 100th anniversary of the Great War, the University of Leicester being Britain\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds only living memorial to the First World War.

You can learn about the\ufffd\ufffdseven milestones on\ufffd\ufffdthe\ufffd\ufffddedicated University website via the links below through podcasts, talks, exhibitions and local and national publicity,:

  1. 1955 - The Making of the English Landscape Published
  2. 1966 - Mass Communication Research enters mainstream academia
  3. 1975 - Searching for Black Holes in Space
  4. 1984 - DNA Fingerprinting discovered
  5. 1994 - Textbook of Hypertension published
  6. 2000 - One of the most important sociologists of the twentieth Century
  7. 2012 - The discovery of Richard III

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Genetics Black holes Magazine:Staff Research WW1 Architecture Astronomy DNA Buildings Education Archaeology Leicester 2013-09-27T09:40:00Z Blog Entry Are we alone in the universe? https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/september/public-lecture-to-explore-if-we-are-alone-in-the-universe Dr Lewis Dartnell to deliver public lecture on Astrobiology and the potential for alien life Dr Lewis Dartnell, a UK Space Agency research fellow based at the University, will deliver a lecture to the public on Thursday, 17 October offering a glimpse into the potential for alien life existing in outer space.

The session will discuss an array of engaging topics, from how life emerged on our planet to where in the cosmos we might expect to find alien life.

Alongside his Astrobiology research, Dr Dartnell writes regular science articles in newspapers and magazines and has appeared in TV shows such as BBC Stargazing live, Wonders of the Universe and Horizon.

Dr Dartnell\ufffd\ufffdhas also published a popular science book introducing Astrobiology entitled\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLife in the Universe: A Beginner\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Guide\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and has illustrated a children\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds book.

The lecture will take place in Room E of the Physics and Astronomy Building Thursday, 17 October from 6.00 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 7.30pm.

]]> No publisher ap507 Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Staff Magazine:Student Space Astronomy 2013-09-26T10:35:00Z Blog Entry University to host major supercomputing event https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/september/university-to-host-major-national-supercomputing-event Department of Physics and Astronomy researchers to present at DiRAC Day 2013 The University\ufffd\ufffdwill host DiRAC Day 2013, a major national supercomputing event, on Monday 23 September 10.30 - 5.00pm, in the Stamford Court Conference Centre.

The team from the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Physics and Astronomy will present the latest scientific advances which have been made possible by the Distributed Research utilising Advanced Computing (DiRAC) supercomputer.

Researchers\ufffd\ufffdfrom Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Theoretical Astrophysics Group within the Department of Physics and Astronomy are currently using the \ufffd\ufffd2 million "Complexity"computer -\ufffd\ufffdthe node of DiRAC hosted by the University - on a number of exciting projects.

During the event, Leicester researchers will also present findings from their other DiRAC research projects \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including planet formation within other solar systems and dark matter.

The DiRAC facility was launched in 2012, and has allowed researchers to model physical processes governing the evolution of the Universe in far greater detail than was previously possible.

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Astronomy Magazine:Student Physics and Astronomy 2013-09-20T15:55:00Z Blog Entry Leicester expert\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research on brown dwarfs features in New Scientist https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/august/leicester-expert2019s-research-on-brown-dwarfs-features-in-new-scientist Dr Sarah Casewell explains extreme weather effects observed on brown dwarfs in close orbit around white dwarfs World-leading research by Dr Sarah Casewell of our Department of Physics and Astronomy has featured in the latest issue of New Scientist magazine.

Dr Casewell is carrying out research into brown dwarfs \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdfailed stars\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd which, unlike stars, are unable to sustain thermonuclear fusion of normal hydrogen in their cores.

Her work particularly focuses on brown dwarfs in close binaries with white dwarfs \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd very dense remnants of low to medium mass stars which have reached the end of their life cycle.

Her expertise in this area made her an ideal person to provide commentary for the New Scientist's piece on brown dwarfs' unusual status as a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhalf star, half planet\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

She explains how brown dwarfs can be locked in orbit around white dwarfs, with only one side ever facing the white dwarf.

As a result, one side will be irradiated by the immensely hot white dwarf while the other side remains cool.

This can produce dramatic weather phenomena according to Dr Casewell \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including supersonic winds which transfer heat from one side of the planet to another.

What\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds more \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd her observations of brown dwarfs can act as a useful proxy for working out what conditions could be like on planets outside our solar system.

Exoplanets tend to be too faint and hard to detect \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd but thankfully, this is not the case with brown dwarfs, which tend to be 13 to 75 times the mass of Jupiter, the largest planet in our solar system.

Dr Casewell uses European Southern Observatory's New Technology Telescope (NTT) and Very Large Telescope (VLT) and the NASA Spitzer Space Telescope to observe four separate brown dwarfs paired with white dwarfs.

\ufffd\ufffd

You can read the full feature in the latest issue of New Scientist (August 24) or on the magazine\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds website (paywall).

]]> No publisher mlrc3 Space Astronomy Magazine:Student Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Magazine:Research 2013-08-30T12:50:02Z Blog Entry University of Leicester leads scientists in bid to understand Universe - using X-rays https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/university-of-leicester-leads-scientists-in-bid-to-understand-universe-using-x-rays-1 Leicester-led research project maps record numbers of cosmic X-ray sources

Three years of research led by\ufffd\ufffdthe University of Leicester has produced a new catalogue of over 500,000 detections of x-ray emissions, and over 300,000 emitters\ufffd\ufffd\ufffda new record, and an unparalleled resource for scientists exploring the extremes of Universe as we know it. The XMM-Newton Survey Science Centre, led by a team from the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Department of Physics and Astronomy, used the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdALICE\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd supercomputer to help them produce a new X-ray catalogue, called \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd3XMM\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

These findings help us map some of the wildest parts of space, and some of the rarest and most extreme phenomena seen in the Universe: for instance prodigious outbursts of X-rays lead us to the tidal disruptions caused by black holes swallowing stars. \ufffd\ufffdAdditionally, the information allows scientists to generate large, well-defined samples of objects, such as active galactic nuclei, which includes galaxies that swirl around supermassive black holes, galactic clusters, which are gargantuan webs containing billions of stars, and stellar coronae\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdthe huge amounts of plasma blasted out into space by stars.

The XMM-Newton Survey Science Centre is one of the teams behind the European Space Agency's (ESA) X-ray Multi-Mirror Mission (XMM-Newton). Since Earth's atmosphere blocks out all X-rays, only a telescope in space can detect and study celestial X-ray sources. The XMM-Newton mission is helping scientists to solve a number of cosmic mysteries, ranging from the enigmatic black holes to the origins of the Universe itself.

]]> No publisher er134 Space Magazine:Staff Space Projects Astronomy Magazine:Student 2013-07-24T09:20:00Z Blog Entry The beginning of time: world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds oldest calendar may have been discovered by archaeologists https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/the-beginning-of-time-world2019s-oldest-calendar-discovered-by-archaeologists University of Leicester archaeoastronomer advises archaeological team on their discovery of what could be the oldest calendarical monument in the world A team of archaeologists has discovered what they believe to be the oldest calendrical monument known anywhere in the world, created by hunter-gatherer societies in Scotland and dating back to around 8000 BC.

Researchers discovered that a monument created by hunter gatherers in Aberdeenshire nearly 10,000 years ago appears to mimic the phases of the Moon in order to track lunar months over the course of a year.

The site, at Warren Field, Crathes, also aligns on the Midwinter Sunrise, providing an annual astronomic correction in order to maintain the link between the passage of time, indicated by the Moon, the asynchronous solar year and the associated seasons.

Clive Ruggles, Emeritus Professor of Archaeoastronomy at the University of Leicester,\ufffd\ufffdadvised the team on archaeoastronomical issues. He points out that there is no evidence that the site marked particular moonrises.

You can read more about the discovery here

]]> No publisher er134 Magazine:Student Astronomy Magazine:Staff Archaeology Archaeoastronomy 2013-07-17T11:17:54Z Blog Entry Leicester Honorary Graduate Jon Culshaw brings the voice of Richard III to the airwaves https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/july/leicester-honorary-graduate-jon-culshaw-2018does2019-richard-iii-on-bbc-radio-leicester University of Leicester degree ceremonies, Career Development Service and fundraising academic all featured on BBC Radio Leicester With the graduation ceremonies in full swing this week, the University featured heavily on BBC Radio Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds drive time show yesterday.

Impressionist and comedian, Jon Culshaw, who was presented with an Honorary Doctorate of Laws for his contributions to astronomy, chatted to presenter Jim Davies of the honour of receiving his Degree and brought along some famous friends - in the form of his impressions. They included the late astronomer Sir Patrick Moore, Hollywood actor Sir Michael Caine, Wimbledon champion Andy Murray and a certain King Richard III.

Staying with the topic of graduation, University of Leicester graduates were quizzed about their future career plans outside the ceremonies at De Montfort Hall.

Rajesh Patel, Employer Liaison Manager at the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Career Development Service talked to Ben Jackson in the studio about the work they are doing to improve our graduates' employability after they finish university.

Finally, Dr Robert Britton a Post-Doctoral Research Associate from the Department of Cancer Studies and Molecular Medicine talked about Pier2Pier, a charity swim he will be taking part in on 14 July, as part of National Transplant Week.

]]> No publisher er134 Careers Astronomy Graduation Cancer Studies and Molecular Medicine Magazine:Staff Honorary graduates Magazine:Student 2013-07-12T14:20:00Z Blog Entry Return to the Red Planet: Leicester could contribute to next mission to Mars https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/june/life-on-mars-university-of-leicester-could-send-technology-to-red-planet University of Leicester displays expertise for future Mars missions to top officials from NASA Top NASA officials met scientists from the University of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Space Research Centre on Tuesday 25 June to see instruments and technologies that could be used for future missions to Mars, ahead of an international meeting on Mars exploration in London. The visitors, including those leading the mission to explore Mars, hoped to discover what the University could contribute to NASA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds next mission to the Red Planet.

Leicester scientists displayed a range of cutting edge technology, including a new rock-splitting technique for obtaining samples, computers which could detect the signs of extreterrestrial life, and techniques for surveying the minerals which make up the surface of the Red Planet\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdall of which could be used on NASA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds next rover mission in 2020.

The Space Research Centre\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Dr John Bridges, Reader\ufffd\ufffdin Planetary Science,\ufffd\ufffdhas already been involved with the Mars Curiosity Rover, which roams the planet\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds red deserts, craters and mountains\ufffd\ufffdin search of life, and this showcase also comes hot on the heels of Leicester\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds work on\ufffd\ufffdthe European Space Agency\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds ExoMars missions, scheduled for 2016 and 2018.

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Astronomy Magazine:Student Physics and Astronomy Space Research Centre Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research 2013-06-28T14:55:00Z Blog Entry Stargazing live has planet-saving bonus https://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/estates/environment/news/2013-news/stargazing-live-has-planet-saving-bonus Stargazing Live achieved a 4% saving in electricity in Ken Edwards, Fielding Johnson and Astley Clarke. If all the lights and unnecessary equipment were switched off in these 3 buildings over every weekend for 1 year, it would power College House for 3 years! Whilst hundreds of people enjoyed the activities on offer when the University hosted Stargazing Live on Jan 8, there was an added environmental benefit.

Staff were asked to make an extra effort to switch lights off to assist the stargazers by removing light pollution from the neighbouring buildings. As well as making the sky easier to see (although the cloud didn't help!), we also achieved  a 4% saving in electricity in Ken Edwards, Fielding Johnson and Astley Clarke.

If all the lights and unnecessary equipment were switched off in these 3 buildings over every weekend for 1 year, it would power College House for 3 years!

So come on guys, it's great that you did it for this event. Please can you do it every day?

]]> No publisher sll33 Environment Sustainability Energy Astronomy 2013-01-23T10:50:39Z Blog Entry How extraterrestrial auroras can help us find other worlds https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2013/january/how-extraterrestrial-auroras-can-help-us-find-other-worlds University of Leicester scientist\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds work on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnorthern lights\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd on other planets featured in New Scientist magazine New Scientist magazine has published a feature on work being carried out by Dr Jonathan Nichols, a Lecturer and Research Fellow in our Department of Physics and Astronomy.

Dr Nichols is carrying out groundbreaking research into how extraterrestrial auroras can be used to detect previously undiscovered planets.

Auroral effects \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd such as the Aurora Borealis seen around our North Pole \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd are not just confined to Earth.

Auroras occur on Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune as well as \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd potentially \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd other planets outside our solar system.

Crucially, auroras emit radio waves \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd meaning that they can be used to detect previously planets which could not be discovered with other methods.

What\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds more, the radio emission could provide us with key information about the length of the planet\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds day, the strength of its magnetic field, how the planet interacts with its parent star and even whether it has any moons.

Dr Nichols is currently studying the auroral effects on planets within our solar system, including Jupiter. This will increase our chances of being able to detect auroral signals from further afield.

He uses a combination of data from spacecraft such as Cassini\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdHuygens, and Earth-orbiting telescopes, including the Hubble Space Telescope. 

You can read the full article here (full article behind paywall).

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Planetary Physics and Astronomy Space Aurora Auroral Astrophysics Astronomy Magazine:Research 2013-01-18T12:12:33Z Blog Entry Reading the Red Planet https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/october/reading-the-red-planet All eyes are on Dr John Bridges \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the Leicester scientist analysing the Mars Curiosity Rover\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds findings. The successful landing of Nasa\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Curiosity Rover on Mars has been one of the biggest science stories of the year \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and University of Leicester planetary scientist Dr John Bridges has played a central role.

Dr Bridges, who is working at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California analysing data sent back from the rover, has been hitting the headlines, with a string of interviews and features on his work with the $2.5 billion project.

The Leicester Mercury reported that the rover has taken its first soil sample from the planet \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd a key stage in the project\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds mission to ascertain whether the planet once supported life. The piece reveals that Dr Bridges has taken a leaf from English naturalist Charles Darwin\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds book Volcanic Islands to gain insight into Martian geology.

Last month, the Leicester Mercury published an in-depth feature on Dr Bridges' involvement, which details the kinds of discoveries the team are hoping to take from Curiosity\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds readings. Among the many things that Dr Bridges was looking forward to about the project was the chance to get a sense of what the Martian landscape really looks like.

Dr Bridges himself has been providing regular updates on the project on his own blog.

]]> No publisher hct16 Magazine:Staff Physics and Astronomy Dr John Bridges Astronomy Physics Magazine:Student 2012-10-16T12:55:00Z Blog Entry Waste of space? No - waste in space https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/october/waste-of-space-no-waste-in-space Leicester scientists involved in major project to use nuclear waste Our space scientists have been making headlines thanks to their involvement in a major international programme to use Britain\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds nuclear waste to power spacecraft.

Researchers at our Space Research Centre, part of our Department of Physics and Astronomy, are working on a European Space Agency (ESA) programme in collaboration with Britain\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds National Nuclear Laboratory (NNL), Astrium UK Ltd and Systems Engineering and Assessment Ltd to develop space nuclear power systems.

The project could potentially make use of the UK\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds stockpile of separated reprocessed plutonium from nuclear power reactors to enable space missions. The researchers believe the use of nuclear power could provide results which would be impossible using solar power \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the primary method of powering space systems currently.

The team hope the benefits of using nuclear waste will include the potential for spacecraft to travel to distant, cold, dark and inhospitable environments which would be inaccessible to crafts relying on solar cells. It is also possible that the extended lifetime of one mission using nuclear power could provide more science value for money.

The University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds involvement in the project is being led by Dr Richard Ambrosi, Dr Hugo Williams and Dr Nigel Bannister of the Space Research Centre.

So far, coverage has appeared in the Financial Times and the Sunday Times (the article is behind a paywall).

]]> No publisher uatemp13 Magazine:Staff Magazine:Research Astronomy Magazine:Student Space Research Centre 2012-10-05T15:40:00Z Blog Entry \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFrom Big Bang to Biospheres\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: Astronomer Royal\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds public lecture on Wednesday 16 May https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/may/2018from-big-bang-to-biospheres2019-astronomer-royal2019s-public-lecture-on-wednesday-16-may Professor Martin Rees asks: How widespread is life in the cosmos? Astronomer Royal Martin Rees (formally, Baron Rees of Ludlow) visits the University on Wednesday to deliver the annual Haldane Society Public Lecture. In his talk \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdFrom Big Bang to Biospheres\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, the former President of the Royal Society will discuss the question of extraterrestrial life.

Should we be surprised that the physical laws have permitted the emergence of complexity of which we are part? Is physical reality even more extensive than the domain our telescopes can probe? Advances in technology mean astronomers have made astonishing progress in probing and understanding our cosmic environment, but they also raise new questions.

We can trace cosmic history from some mysterious 'beginning' nearly 14 billion years ago. We understand in outline how atoms, galaxies, stars and planets emerged. And we know how, on at least one planet, life emerged and developed a complex biosphere of which we are part. But what does the long-range future hold?

As well as being the Astronomer Royal, Martin Rees is Master of Trinity College, Cambridge and a visiting Professor at Imperial College London. He was appointed to the House of Lords in 2005. He is the author of more than 500 scientific papers and numerous books including the acclaimed Just Six Numbers: The Deep Forces That Shape the Universe. And Asteroid 4587 is named after him.

The lecture, which is free and open to the public, will take place in the Ken Edwards Building, Lecture Theatre 1, at 6.00pm on Wednesday 16 May 2012 and will be followed by a wine reception in the Charles Wilson Building.

The Haldane Society, hosted by the University of Leicester was established almost half a century ago as a meeting place for \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtown and gown\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. Its purpose is to hear distinguished speakers address topics drawn from a wide range of subjects, but always involving the boundary between academic study and practical, everyday concerns.

]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Television Honorary graduates Astronomy Magazine:Student 2012-02-03T09:45:00Z Blog Entry Honorary Graduates No.2 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Nigel Henbest https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/january/honorary-graduates-no.2-2013-nigel-henbest Leicester astronomy alumnus with a ticket for space. It\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds been a busy old week for astronomy in Leicester. Here at the University, we presented four public lectures on astronomy, three of them tied into the BBC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Stargazing Live event. Over at the National Space Centre, Sir Patrick Moore (an old friend of ours who is a Distinguished Honorary Fellow and a contributor to our Leicester Exchanges site) officially opened the Sir Patrick Moore Planetarium. At the start of the week, astronomers were squinting Northwards hoping for a glimpse of an unusually strong Aurora borealis (unsuccessfully, alas). And today, Nigel Henbest picks up an Honorary Degree at De Montfort Hall.

Born in Manchester, raised in Belfast, Nigel studied Astrophysics here at Leiceter where he met Heather Couper, forming a lifelong friendship which would produce innumerable books and television programmes about space and astronomy. In fact, his first published article was in the newsletter of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Physics Society.

After postgraduate study at Cambridge, he returned to Leicester to help with the development and installation of equipment to monitor the Sicilian volcano Mount Etna. In the days before GPS, Henbest navigated his Landrover across Europe using The World Atlas of Wine!

Together with Heather Couper and Stuart Carter, Nigel Henbest set up Pioneer Productions to make science programming. Over the years he has written nearly 40 books and hundreds of magazine articles (and a stage play) about astronomy. He has been Astronomy Consultant to New Scientist, Media Consultant to the Royal Greenwich Observatory, Editor of the Journal of the British Astronomical Association, Chairman of National Astronomy Week and External Assessor on Astronomy to the Open University.

Last March, Nigel and Heather - who now run the media science consultancy Hencoup Enterprises - came back to Leicester to present the annual Alumni Lecture. Heather already has an Honorary Doctorate of Science, awarded in 1994. Nigel collects his this afternoon in the 4.00pm Graduation Ceremony.

And in less than two years' time, all being well, Nigel should finally make it into space for real, having already bought a ticket for the Virgin Galactic spaceship!
